articles.headline: An Aging Boy Band Calls It Quits, but Japan Can’t Let Go
articles.snippet: The nation is awash with anguish over the announcement of a breakup by SMAP, whose youngest member is now pushing 40.
articles.abstract: The nation is awash with anguish over the announcement of a breakup by SMAP, whose youngest member is now pushing 40.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For nearly three decades, millions of Japanese have clamored for their every album, lined up with breathless anticipation for their concerts and gathered on Monday nights for their hit television show.

articles.headline: Lyft Is Said to Seek a Buyer, Without Success
articles.snippet: The talks underline how difficult it has become to operate in the ride-hailing market, where people can book rides from drivers through a smartphone app.
articles.abstract: The talks underline how difficult it has become to operate in the ride-hailing market, where people can book rides from drivers through a smartphone app.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is not an easy thing to be an independent ride-hailing company these days.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Bloated Pay Came Before Hain Celestial’s Error
articles.snippet: Investors were stunned when Hain said it had an accounting problem, but clues to oversight problems had been evident for a while in the company’s excessive executive pay.
articles.abstract: Investors were stunned when Hain said it had an accounting problem, but clues to oversight problems had been evident for a while in the company’s excessive executive pay.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Hain Celestial Group, a maker of natural and organic foods and beverages, has been riding high in the market. But on Monday it came crashing to earth when it disclosed an accounting problem, delayed its full-year financial report and said it probably wouldn’t meet its earnings guidance for 2016.

articles.headline: At Viacom, Now Comes the Hard Part
articles.snippet: A struggling media empire, still aching from a legal war involving Sumner M. Redstone, must focus on winning the peace.
articles.abstract: A struggling media empire, still aching from a legal war involving Sumner M. Redstone, must focus on winning the peace.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1987, Sumner M. Redstone wrested control of Viacom in a hostile corporate takeover that left scorched relationships with the company’s management. Still bitter, executives sent Thomas E. Dooley, Viacom’s 30-year-old treasurer, to greet Mr. Redstone when he visited the Viacom office, the new boss wearing a plaid jacket bought on his way, the Filene’s Basement price tag still visible.

articles.headline: Private Equity Pursues Profits in Keeping the Elderly at Home
articles.snippet: PACE, a Medicare program that helps keep older people in their own homes, is allowing for-profit companies in. Tech and venture capital have expressed interest.
articles.abstract: PACE, a Medicare program that helps keep older people in their own homes, is allowing for-profit companies in. Tech and venture capital have expressed interest.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Inside a senior center here, nestled along a bustling commercial strip, Vivian Malveaux scans her bingo card for a winning number. Her 81-year-old eyes are warm, lively and occasionally set adrift by the dementia plundering her mind.

articles.headline: A Mail Boat Stays Afloat
articles.snippet: The J.W. Westcott II — the only boat with its own ZIP code — sails from Detroit delivering parcels and pizzas to sailors on the Great Lakes.
articles.abstract: The J.W. Westcott II — the only boat with its own ZIP code — sails from Detroit delivering parcels and pizzas to sailors on the Great Lakes.
articles.lead_paragraph: A narrow street dead-ends at the Detroit River, where a black-and-white boat bobs in the water, emblazoned with a Postal Service eagle. This is the mail boat J.W. Westcott II, the only floating ZIP code in the United States.

articles.headline: Trump’s Empire: A Maze of Debts and Opaque Ties
articles.snippet: A review of the Republican presidential nominee’s holdings uncovered more debt than what is apparent on his federal election filing, and partnerships with even more liabilities.
articles.abstract: A review of the Republican presidential nominee’s holdings uncovered more debt than what is apparent on his federal election filing, and partnerships with even more liabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, has sold himself as a businessman who has made billions of dollars and is beholden to no one.

articles.headline: More of Kremlin’s Opponents Are Ending Up Dead
articles.snippet: Mysterious deaths and close calls have some opposition figures worried that political murder is resurgent in Russian foreign policy.
articles.abstract: Mysterious deaths and close calls have some opposition figures worried that political murder is resurgent in Russian foreign policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — From a certain perspective, certainly the Kremlin’s, Vladimir Kara-Murza’s behavior in Washington could be seen as treasonous, a brazen betrayal of his homeland.

articles.headline: Affluent and Black, and Still Trapped by Segregation
articles.snippet: Why well-off black families end up living in poorer areas than white families with similar or even lower incomes.
articles.abstract: Why well-off black families end up living in poorer areas than white families with similar or even lower incomes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Their daughter was sick and they needed family around to help care for her, so JoAnne and Maanaan Sabir took an unexpected detour.
articles.byline: By John Eligon and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: Foundation Ties Bedevil Hillary Clinton’s Presidential Campaign
articles.snippet: The funding of the sprawling philanthropy has become an Achilles’ heel for Mrs. Clinton’s White House bid and, if she is victorious, potentially her administration as well.
articles.abstract: The funding of the sprawling philanthropy has become an Achilles’ heel for Mrs. Clinton’s White House bid and, if she is victorious, potentially her administration as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: The kingdom of Saudi Arabia donated more than $10 million. Through a foundation, so did the son-in-law of a former Ukrainian president whose government was widely criticized for corruption and the murder of journalists. A Lebanese-Nigerian developer with vast business interests contributed as much as $5 million.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Steve Eder

articles.headline: Syria’s Horrors Visit Turkey Again as Bomber Attacks Kurdish Wedding
articles.snippet: The suicide attack, which killed more than 50, is the deadliest in a string of bombings in Turkey as the war in Syria spills over the border.
articles.abstract: The suicide attack, which killed more than 50, is the deadliest in a string of bombings in Turkey as the war in Syria spills over the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The wedding on Saturday night was winding down, and some guests had already left. But the music was still playing and people were still dancing in the narrow streets of Gaziantep, a city not far from the Syrian border.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Ceylan Yeginsu

articles.headline: Donald Trump, a ‘Rigged’ Election and the Politics of Race
articles.snippet: Observers say the Republican nominee’s warnings of voter fraud in Pennsylvania belie his real target: predominately black precincts like those in Philadelphia that traditionally vote for Democrats.
articles.abstract: Observers say the Republican nominee’s warnings of voter fraud in Pennsylvania belie his real target: predominately black precincts like those in Philadelphia that traditionally vote for Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he seeks to revive his embattled candidacy, Donald J. Trump has seized on a new argument to rally his supporters and to explain away a possible defeat in November: that Democrats are preparing to exploit weak voter identification laws to win a “stolen election” through fraudulent voting.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Rent-to-Own Homes: A Win-Win for Landlords, a Risk for Struggling Tenants
articles.snippet: A new breed of landlord is blurring the line between renter and homeowner, but these firms claim they’re bringing homeownership to those who can’t get mortgages.
articles.abstract: A new breed of landlord is blurring the line between renter and homeowner, but these firms claim they’re bringing homeownership to those who can’t get mortgages.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Alex Szkaradek is a landlord who seems to have the best of both worlds.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: To Crack Down on Securities Fraud, States Reward Whistle-Blowers
articles.snippet: In return for helping states to enforce securities fraud laws and protect residents from financial harm, confidential informants earn a piece of the penalty.
articles.abstract: In return for helping states to enforce securities fraud laws and protect residents from financial harm, confidential informants earn a piece of the penalty.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of the financial crisis, a growing army of confidential informants — better known as whistle-blowers — has helped federal securities regulators identify and prosecute wrongdoers.

articles.headline: Obama Readies One Last Push for Trans-Pacific Partnership
articles.snippet: As both presidential candidates campaign against it, the White House is negotiating with Republicans in Congress to ratify the largest regional trade agreement ever.
articles.abstract: As both presidential candidates campaign against it, the White House is negotiating with Republicans in Congress to ratify the largest regional trade agreement ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — His successor, whether Democrat or Republican, opposes it, as does most of his party. Delegates at the Democratic National Convention waved signs saying “T.P.P.” slashed by a bold line, while the Republican Party platform opposed any vote on it in Congress this year.

articles.headline: After Olympics, Rio Is Altered if Not Reborn
articles.snippet: There have been cost overruns and many other complaints, but the 2016 Summer Games in Rio also yielded infrastructure improvements that had been on wish lists for years.
articles.abstract: There have been cost overruns and many other complaints, but the 2016 Summer Games in Rio also yielded infrastructure improvements that had been on wish lists for years.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — There have been cost overruns and complaints about spending billions on a mega-event when teachers have gone unpaid. Critics say upscale areas have been favored at the expense of slum dwellers. A pledge to clean up Rio de Janeiro’s polluted bay went unfulfilled, while the promise of law and order now feels like a cruel taunt in the face of rising crime.

articles.headline: Bay Area Start-Ups Find Low-Cost Outposts in Arizona
articles.snippet: After struggling with high salaries and soaring housing costs, some Silicon Valley tech companies expanded outward to areas where they could grow quickly and make jobs more appealing.
articles.abstract: After struggling with high salaries and soaring housing costs, some Silicon Valley tech companies expanded outward to areas where they could grow quickly and make jobs more appealing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Three years ago, Kate Rogers was caught in the Bay Area struggle. She paid the astronomical rents. She did the crushing commute. She lived the frustration of always thinking about money even though she was a well-paid professional in the booming technology industry.

articles.headline: Sean Hannity Turns Adviser in the Service of Donald Trump
articles.snippet: Mr. Hannity has given Mr. Trump and those around him suggestions on strategy and messaging while still hosting his show on Fox News.
articles.abstract: Mr. Hannity has given Mr. Trump and those around him suggestions on strategy and messaging while still hosting his show on Fox News.
articles.lead_paragraph: During major inflection points in Donald J. Trump’s campaign, the advisers, family members and friends who make up his kitchen cabinet burn up their email accounts and phone lines gaming out how to get his candidacy on track (and what counsel he might go along with).

articles.headline: Donald Trump, With Bare-Bones Campaign, Relies on G.O.P. for Vital Tasks
articles.snippet: As campaign documents revealed a spending gap between Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton, some Republican leaders called for focusing resources on candidates down the ballot.
articles.abstract: As campaign documents revealed a spending gap between Mr. Trump and Hillary Clinton, some Republican leaders called for focusing resources on candidates down the ballot.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is leaning heavily on Republican Party organizations to provide crucial campaign functions like getting out the vote, digital outreach and fund-raising, at a time when some leading Republicans have called for party officials to cut off Mr. Trump and focus instead on maintaining control of Congress.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Rachel Shorey

articles.headline: Supreme Court to Consider Legal Standard Drawn From ‘Of Mice and Men’
articles.snippet: The court will consider whether Texas’ Court of Criminal Appeals erred in upholding the death sentence of an intellectually disabled man based in part on “the Lennie standard.”
articles.abstract: The court will consider whether Texas’ Court of Criminal Appeals erred in upholding the death sentence of an intellectually disabled man based in part on “the Lennie standard.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2002, the Supreme Court barred the execution of the intellectually disabled. But it gave states a lot of leeway to decide just who was, in the language of the day, “mentally retarded.”

articles.headline: Pfizer to Buy Cancer Drug Maker in $14 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: The frenzy over Medivation, which makes treatments for prostate and breast cancers, shows what pharmaceutical companies are willing to pay for oncology deals.
articles.abstract: The frenzy over Medivation, which makes treatments for prostate and breast cancers, shows what pharmaceutical companies are willing to pay for oncology deals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Medivation, which makes the big-selling drug Xtandi to treat prostate cancer, has finally found its buyer in a fellow American drug maker, Pfizer.
articles.byline: By Andrew Pollack and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Japan, Seeking to Regain Manufacturing Might, Bets on Aerospace
articles.snippet: The Mitsubishi Regional Jet has become a symbol of national pride and industrial renewal, but it is plagued by delays and cost overruns.
articles.abstract: The Mitsubishi Regional Jet has become a symbol of national pride and industrial renewal, but it is plagued by delays and cost overruns.
articles.lead_paragraph: GIFU, Japan — Kato Manufacturing, based in the blue-collar enclave of Gifu Prefecture, in central Japan, is a microcosm of the country’s industrial evolution.
